item.title: My Bubble of Protection
item.description: Lucy Davis, a 15-year old Family History Consultant, talks about her experiences helping others and the blessings that she and her family receive from doing temple and family history work.

item.title: Find, Take, Teach
item.description: Elder Quentin L. Cook outlined a new focus on finding a name, taking it to the temple, and teaching others to do the same.

item.title: RootsTech 2015: The Promised Blessings of Family History
item.description: This video has all the recent promises given by general authorities about doing family history work, and how it will bless our lives here and now, not just our deceased ancestors.

item.title: Our Father's Plan Is About Families
item.description: Elder Quentin L. Cook teaches the blessings that come to families as they discover their family history together.

item.title: Sharing the Temple Challenge
item.description: Elder Andersen talks about the many blessings and promises that come from accepting the challenge to find and take a name of one of your own ancestors to the temple.

item.title: Family History Blesses Families
item.description: Knowing your family history, learning about your ancestors, and serving them through temple ordinances brings blessings not only to them but also to the living.

item.title: RootsTech 2015: Healing Families
item.description: Mandy Phillips accepts Elder Andersen's temple challenge and is reunited with her grandparents she hasn't seen in 20 years.

item.title: Blessings to the Living through Family History
item.description: Elders L. Whitney Clayton, Allan F. Packer, and Kent F. Richards discuss the blessings that come to the living through temple and family history work.

item.title: Consultant Training - Different People, Different Trees: Teaching to Individual Needs
item.description: Learn how to identify the most common tree situations.

item.title: Teaching Family History in Your Home, Class or Quorum
item.description: In this session you will learn about resources and methods for teaching family history.

item.title: Consultant Training: Using FamilySearch Partners
item.description: Hasten your family history woork through FamilySearch partners.

item.title: FamilySearch Family Tree 2014 and Beyond
item.description: This class will give an update on the current status of Family Tree and its latest features.

item.title: FamilySearch Indexing: It's a Whole New World!
item.description: An overview of the powerful new features and volunteer opportunities in the new indexing program.

item.title: What's New at FamilySearch
item.description: What are the latest tools from FamilySearch, and how do I use them?

item.title: From Tree to Temple: Preparing Family Names for the Temple
item.description: This class will help you prepare an ancestor's name for temple ordinances.

item.title: It's About the Dash
item.description: Elder Bradley D. Foster demonstrates how easy family history can be, and discusses new changes to Familysearch.org

item.title: Including Me
item.description: This video shows how a little girl's prayers that her family would be sealed in the temple were answered.

item.title: Because of James
item.description: This video shows how one young man responded to Elder Bednar's invitation by involving his entire family in family history and temple work.

item.title: He Was a Blacksmith
item.description: This video shows how family history consultants find creative ways to involve an entire family in family history and temple work.

item.title: Watching My Grandson Play Ball
item.description: In this video, Elder Tad R. Callister relates how his grandfather missed an important meeting to watch him play softball.

item.title: Now I'm Converted
item.description: This video shows how the youth in one stake were blessed as they responded to Elder Bednar's invitation to participate in family history.

item.title: Youth Temple Challenge: Unifying my Young Women
item.description: A young women's leader accepts Elder Andersen's temple challenge to the youth and discovers a way to increase the spirituality and unity of her young women through finding ancestors and attending the temple to do their ordinances for them. To get started finding your family members needing temple saving ordinances, visit FamilySearch.org

item.title: Time Well Spent
item.description: A couple in England shares how doing family history work has enhanced their experiences in the temple. They show the application of a principle outlined by Elder Richard G. Scott that "any work you do in the temple is time well spent, but receiving ordinances vicariously for one of your own ancestors will make the time in the temple more sacred." To get started finding your family members needing temple saving ordinances, visit FamilySearch.org.

item.title: #MeetMyGrandma
item.description: People from all over the world and all walks of life recall why their Grandmother is so special.

item.title: Be An Example Like She Was
item.description: A woman wrestling with the struggles of having a husband who is inactive in the Church finds strength in learning about a faithful ancestor who dealt with the same thing.

item.title: Youth Rising to the Call
item.description: Youth share how they are rising to the call issued by Church leadership to lead the way in the hastening of the work of salvation for both the living and the dead.

item.title: Now We're Sealed—Now It's Forever
item.description: This video illustrates how family history work can create a desire to help a new member receive the blessings of the temple.

item.title: Discovery Through Stories
item.description: A family history consultant helps a priesthood leader and his family get excited about doing family history.

item.title: She Wanted Me to Find Her
item.description: A new family history consultant shares her experience of finding her ancestor's name and going to the temple.

item.title: An Enhanced Temple Experience
item.description: Two families take their own family name to the temple for the first time.

item.title: Hannah's View
item.description: A young child shares her perspective about life, the temple, and family history.

item.title: If We Put God First
item.description: A young woman facing adversity shares how she was strengthened by setting aside the things of the world and putting God first.

item.title: My Full Conversion
item.description: A Church member describes how her conversion to the Gospel was solidified through temple and family history work.

item.title: My Calm in the Storm
item.description: A young single adult shares her perspective about her busy life and taking control of her peace and happiness. She explains how temple and family history work is her calm in the storm.

item.title: I Love My Red Hair
item.description: Alanah tells about having success finding an ancestor at the Family History Library.

item.title: Storm Front
item.description: A woman learns how to overcome trials and the difficult circumstances she has been placed in by learning from the example of her ancestor.

item.title: Turning Hearts
item.description: A Great-Grandfather's journal helps a young man gain direction in his life and appreciation for his ancestors.

item.title: Mine Eyes Have Seen The Glory
item.description: July Ward Howe, who wrote The Battle Hymn of the Republic, inspires later generations, including her great-great-great-grandson with her writings and push for social change.

item.title: Letters From Estonia
item.description: Family history research helps one woman have a greater understanding of her grandfather's life and builds a new connection with family in Estonia.

item.title: Clan McCloud
item.description: How do you connect with your ancestors? How about learning to play the Great Highland Bagpipe.

item.title: Searching For Emma
item.description: Finding strength in the past, one woman learns about her Great-Grandmother Emma's sacrifice for her posterity and the legacy she left behind.

item.title: Woven Generations - FamilySearch Ancestral Research
item.description: Video introduction to segments originally shown at "A Celebration of Family History" as part of the 2010 NGS Conference held in Salt Lake City.

item.title: Fulfillment of Prophecy
item.description: Two youth learn through searching out names of their own ancestors and then performing their ordinances in the temple that they are literally fulfilling prophecies laid out in the Book of Mormon.

item.title: Be An Example Like She Was
item.description: A woman wrestling with the struggles of having a husband who is inactive in the Church finds strength in learning about a faithful ancestor who dealt with the same thing.

item.title: Youth Rising to the Call
item.description: Youth share how they are rising to the call issued by Church leadership to lead the way in the hastening of the work of salvation for both the living and the dead.

item.title: Heritage of Hope
item.description: President Henry B. Eyring shares how reading stories of his great-grandfather has taught him about his heritage of hope and how we all have that inheritance because of our savior, Jesus Christ

item.title: You Will See Patterns
item.description: Elder Neil L. Andersen encourages members to find the names of family members who have passed on and to take their names to the temple.

item.title: Help Wanted
item.description: Linda K. Burton, General Relief Society President, presents the spiritual "help wanted" signs we might identify in our lives -- doing family history and temple work.

item.title: My Family Booklet
item.description: Elder Quentin L. Cook testifies of the importance of family history work in conjunction with temple work to save our dead and link families eternally.

item.title: Promise of Protection
item.description: Sister Linda S. Reeves, second counselor in the General Relief Society presidency, reminds us of the prophetic promise of protection if we search out our ancestors.

item.title: Heavy Lifting
item.description: Elder Quentin L. Cook advises "much of the heavy lifting and hastening of the work of salvation for both the living and the dead will be done by you young people."

item.title: First Stories of Faith
item.description: Elder William R. Walker of the Seventy encourages connecting with righteous forefathers by learning of their stories of faith and sacrifice.

item.title: Don’t Underestimate the Deceased
item.description: Elder Quentin L. Cook testifies of the importance of family history work in conjunction with temple work to save our dead and link families eternally.

item.title: Family Commitments
item.description: Elder Quentin L. Cook encourages the nourishing of our roots and branches as they relate to family history work to ensure our divine destiny as eternal families.

item.title: Family Tree Gatherings
item.description: Elder Quentin L. Cook introduces the idea of "Family Tree Gatherings" as a way to turn the hearts of the children to the fathers in the hastening of family history work.

item.title: Saviors on Mt. Zion
item.description: By performing vicarious ordinances for our dead in the temple, we can literally be saviors on Mount Zion. From Elder Quentin L. Cook's April 2014 General Conference talk entitled "Roots and Branches".

item.title: Lifting Sisters
item.description: While speaking at the 2014 world-wide Women's Conference, President Henry B. Eyring shared how the Lord is lifting sisters to higher and higher levels of spirituality.

item.title: I Found Him
item.description: God will guide you to your family as you do your family history work.

item.title: Youth Doing the Work
item.description: Feel the Spirit as you do something really important.

item.title: Courage: I Think I Get It from Him
item.description: Learn about your ancestors strengths to discover your own strengths.

item.title: Your Fingers Have Been Trained
item.description: The youth have been prepared to participate in temple and family history work.

item.title: Maybe I'm Not So Different
item.description: Keeping a journal helps us preserve memories of seeing the Lord's hand in our lives.

item.title: Do Something That Really Matters
item.description: Service to your family is eternal, set aside time to serve the ones who love you most.

item.title: It's Changed Me
item.description: Youth feel the Spirit and realize they are doing something important as they take family names to the temple.

item.title: Share Your Names
item.description: Blessings come from sharing the names you have reserved for temple ordinances.

item.title: I Can Have My Husband Forever
item.description: Discover the joy of eternal connections across generations. We can be connected together forever.

item.title: The Turning of Our Hearts: San Salvador, El Salvador
item.description: Families in the San Salvador Los Heroes Stake are blessed in numerous ways when they accept an invitation to do family history and temple work.

item.title: The Turning of Our Hearts: Rio Rancho, New Mexico, U.S.
item.description: Members of the Rio Rancho New Mexico Stake are blessed in ways they never imagined when they accept an invitation to do family history and temple work.

item.title: Glad Tidings: The History of Baptisms for the Dead
item.description: Joseph Smith's struggle with his brother Alvin's death led eventually to the introduction of baptisms for the dead. This new ordinance was embraced by saints in Nauvoo who did the first genealogical and family history research in Church history.

item.title: Their Hearts Are Bound To You
item.description: President Henry B. Eyring poignantly describes why our family are so important to us, not only now but for forever. The Mormon Tabernacle choir punctuates the doctrine in song.

item.title: To Turn The Hearts Featured
item.description: This video includes real-life examples of how the leaders in one stake used temple and family history work to strengthen individuals and families.

item.title: Family History Center Director: Supporting Priesthood Goals
item.description: Family history center directors and priesthood leaders discuss how they can work together to accomplish stake goals.

item.title: Family History Center Director: Working with Youth and Young Adults
item.description: Tips and suggestions from family history center directors and priesthood leaders on how to involve youth and young adults in family history work.

item.title: Family History Center Director: Understanding My Calling
item.description: Ideas and insights to help new family history center directors understand what they do in their calling and the rewards of working in a family history center.

item.title: Family History Center Director: Promoting the Center
item.description: Family history center directors share ideas on how to promote the center and involve members with family history work.

item.title: Family History for the Whole Family
item.description: Children can be involved in family history as well as adults. This video shows one family's experience of doing family history together.

item.title: First Hearts, then Charts
item.description: The Aguilar family uses the paper process and a FH consultant to find their ancestors.

item.title: Area Family History Adviser Training–Meeting with Leaders
item.description: This video shows area family history advisers meeting with stake leaders to demonstrate how family history can be a resource in the work of salvation.

item.title: Rise To Your Call
item.description: President Eyring describes the significance, blessings, and impact of your calling.

item.title: Assist the Ward Council–Working with Youth
item.description: This video shows how ward leaders and those with family history callings can help the youth participate in and lead family history efforts.

item.title: Family History Consultants Tip #1–Start with Stories
item.description: This video shows how family history consultants can help members by seeking inspiration, focusing on stories, and testifying of the blessings of temple and family history work.

item.title: Family History Consultants Tip #4–Help them act in faith
item.description: This video shows how family history consultants can help members by building faith and allowing them to act and to discover for themselves.

item.title: Family History Consultants Tip #5–Help them to progress
item.description: This video shows how family history consultants can help members progress by following up, being patient, and focusing on the positive.

item.title: Family History Consultants Tip #3–Teach people, not lessons
item.description: This video shows how family history consultants can help members by adapting to their needs, being prepared, asking them what they want to do, and focusing on stories.

item.title: Family History Consultants Tip #2–Help them have a positive experience
item.description: This video shows how family history consultants can help members have a positive experience by encouraging early success, building their confidence, and being a friend.

item.title: "I'm a Family History Center Director" Sister Maria Manrique
item.description: Sister Maria Manrique from Lima, Peru explains how serving as a FamilySearch missionary helped prepare her to become a Family History Center Director.

item.title: Family History: Not a Program of the Church, But a Principle of the Gospel
item.description: Family History: Not a Program of the Church, But a Principle of the Gospel

item.title: YSA Ward gets involved with family history
item.description: Michael Melendez teaches his YSA ward how to get involved and enjoy doing family history work.

item.title: Training For My Calling: Area Family History Adviser
item.description: This video shows the role of the Area Family History Adviser in using temple and family history responsibilities to strengthen families and individuals in their Stakes and Wards.

item.title: Training For My Calling: Family History Consultant
item.description: This video shows the role of the Family History Consultant in using temple and family history responsibilities to strengthen families and individuals in their Ward.

item.title: This Is The Work Of Salvation – Condensed
item.description: A family history consultant helps a priesthood leader and his family get excited about doing family history.

item.title: High Priests Group Leader: Direct the Work of Consultants
item.description: This video shows how the high priests group leader directs the work of family history consultants by providing assignments and training resources and how he works with the bishopric to ensure enough consultants are called to meet the ward’s needs.

item.title: Let Youth Lead Their Family History Experience
item.description: Elder Bednar speaks of Youth doing Family History and how the youth in Kansas City embraced and succeeded in the work.

item.title: The Turning of Our Hearts: Springfield, Illinois, U.S.
item.description: The Jess family was in trouble. Praying to resolve issues that were threatening to dissolve the family. Watch as they enlist family to turn hearts and literally save themselves, and generations to come.

item.title: One Million Names Indexed
item.description: The Sacramento, California (United States) Stake made a goal to index one million names in one month. They didn’t know what an impact it would have on the stake. View this video to see the blessings that come from indexing and family history.

item.title: Let Them Act
item.description: Elder Bednar offers counsel on how to help youth act for themselves.

item.title: New Members And Retention: Dauphinee Family
item.description: After getting married and starting a family, Michael Dauphinee and his wife Jessica felt the need to go to church. See how family history has helped them grow in the gospel.

item.title: Activation: Paul Felix
item.description: Paul Felix became an Elder before entering the Air Force. After getting married he always thought his wife would join the church. Now after years of inactivity and the passing of his wife he is coming back to church and going to the temple.

item.title: Training For My Calling: Ward Council
item.description: This video shows the role of the Ward Council in using temple and family history responsibilities to strengthen families and individuals in their Ward.

item.title: Missionary Work And Retention: Georgia Elias
item.description: Georgia Elias is converted to the gospel through family history work and begins her journey to the temple.

item.title: Strengthen Youth
item.description: Using the temple and family history work to strengthen youth

item.title: Springfield Leaders Secrets of Success
item.description: Leaders from the Springfield Stake share their experiences using temple and family history work to strengthen families and individuals and bring them closer to Christ.

item.title: To Turn The Hearts Condensed
item.description: This video includes real-life examples of how the leaders in one stake used temple and family history work to strengthen individuals and families. -Condensed

item.description: This video shows the role of the Stake President in using temple and family history responsibilities to strengthen families and individuals in their Stake.

item.description: This video shows the role of the High Priests Group Leader in using temple and family history responsibilities to strengthen families and individuals in their Ward.

item.description: This video shows the role of the High Councilor in using temple and family history responsibilities to strengthen families and individuals in their Stake.

item.description: Lucy Davis, a 15-year old Family History Consultant, talks about her experiences helping others and the blessings that she and her family receive from doing temple and family history work.

item.title: Family History: An Invitation
item.description: Elder David A. Bednar speaks at the 2011 October General Conference.

item.title: RootsTech 2015: Sharing the Temple Challenge
item.description: After accepting and accomplishing the temple challenge, Lauren Hatch teaches her family what she learned.

item.title: Sam Hepworth Mission Prep Video
item.description: Accepting Elder Neil L. Andersen’s temple challenge and sharing it with others helped Sam Hepworth prepare for his mission.

item.title: RootsTech 2015: Healing Families
item.description: Mandy Phillips accepts Elder Andersen's temple challenge and is reunited with her grandparents she hasn't seen in 20 years. See Elder Andersen give the Temple Challenge.

item.title: Sharing the Temple Challenge
item.description: Elder Andersen talks about the many blessings and promises that come from accepting the challenge to find and take a name of one of your own ancestors to the temple.

item.title: One Million Names Indexed
item.description: The Sacramento, California (United States) Stake made a goal to index one million names in one month. They didn’t know what an impact it would have on the stake. View this video to see the blessings that come from indexing and family history.

item.title: Youth in Campinas, Brazil Catch Indexing Spirit
item.description: The director of the family history center adjacent to the Campinas Brazil Temple started inviting visiting youth to participate in indexing when not in the temple. As a result, young people index thousands of names at the center.

item.title: Youth Rising to the Call
item.description: Youth share how they are rising to the call issued by Church leadership to lead the way in the hastening of the work of salvation for both the living and the dead.

item.title: Fulfillment of Prophecy
item.description: Two youth learn through searching out names of their own ancestors and then performing their ordinances in the temple that they are literally fulfilling prophecies laid out in the Book of Mormon.

item.title: Temple Challenge
item.description: Elder Neil L. Andersen of the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles has issued a challenge to youth to help prepare as many names for the temple as baptisms they perform in the temple.

item.title: Elder Neil L. Andersen – Family History Work is for Youth
item.description: Elder Neil L. Andersen spoke to a group of youth at RootsTech conference on February 8, 2014. He explained why they have been prepared at this time and how they can be involved in family history work.

item.title: Find Our Cousins
item.description: When doing your family history, don’t just go straight back, but look for your cousins too. If you find a full tree, help others with theirs.

item.title: Your Fingers Have Been Trained
item.description: The youth have been prepared to participate in temple and family history work.

item.title: Now I'm Converted
item.description: This video shows how the youth in one stake were blessed as they responded to Elder Bednar's invitation to participate in family history.

item.title: She Wanted Me to Find Her
item.description: A new family history consultant shares her experience of finding her ancestor's name and going to the temple.

item.title: If We Put God First
item.description: A young woman facing adversity shares how she was strengthened by setting aside the things of the world and putting God first.

item.title: I Was Chosen
item.description: Two teenagers share how they simultaneously blessed their own lives, their family members, andtheir ancestors.

item.title: You Will Have Divine Help in Family History
item.description: Thomas' story of his endeavors to find family members for whom he could perform temple work. It explores the efforts of youth in the Church to do Family History research.

item.title: Family History prepares Eduardo for his mission
item.description: Doing family history strengthened Educardo's testomony of the plan of salvation and prepared him for his mission.

item.title: Three YM in France share their love and testimony of family history
item.description: Three young men talk about their ancestors and how finding out about them has turned their hearts to their fathers.

item.title: French brothers talk about doing temple work for their ancestors
item.description: Hear the story of two brothers who did the baptisms for their ancestors and set an example for their younger brother, who now continues doing work for their deceased ancestors and shares in the blessings.

item.title: The youth of the Peru Santanita Stake answer Elder Bednar's challenge
item.description: The youth of the Peru Santanita stake accepted Elder Bednar's challenge and are receiving the promised blessings.

item.title: Luis and Henry Connecting Families Through Indexing
item.description: Listen to two young men from Peru, Luis and Henry, as they bear testimony of service through indexing.

item.title: YM Eagle Scout Project Indexing Family History Records
item.description: The story of how one young man caught the spirit of why indexing historical records is important and used it for his Eagle Scout service project.

item.title: Pizza and Family History
item.description: Jordan Hintze discovers that family history can be fun and delicious.

item.title: I Found My Great-Grandfather
item.description: My testimony was strengthened when I found the records for my great-grandfather and did the temple work for him.

item.title: I Love My Red Hair
item.description: Alanah tells about having success finding an ancestor at the Family History Library.

item.title: The Time is Now
item.description: Elder Bednar and youth talk about doing family history research and the importance of engaging in the work of the temple.

item.title: Finding Our Cousins: Using New Tools on FamilySearch.org
item.description: This video shows how to find family members using the new Descendancy view on FamilySearch.org.

item.title: Preserve Your Photos And Family Memories
item.description: Keep, protect, and share photos and stories on FamilySearch, where families live forever.

item.title: Discover Your Family History. Discover Your Story.
item.description: Every family has a story. What's yours? Learn more about your story and find strength for your life in the example and experiences of your ancestors.

item.title: FamilySearch Indexing: Get Started!
item.description: Interested in learning how to index? Watch this video and learn how easy it is to download and register for FamilySearch Indexing.

item.title: It's About the Dash
item.description: Elder Bradley D. Foster demonstrates how easy family history can be, and discusses new changes to Familysearch.org

item.title: Watching My Grandson Play Ball
item.description: In this video, Elder Tad R. Callister relates how his grandfather missed an important meeting to watch him play softball.

item.title: Step 1: Discover Your Story
item.description: Learn how to discover more about who you are by learning the stories of your ancestors.

item.title: Step 2: Explore Your Family Tree
item.description: Learn how to explore the Family Tree and get started finding your ancestors.

item.title: Step 3: Find and Serve Your Ancestors
item.description: Learn how to find your ancestors through historical records, and then serve them by performing temple ordinances on their behalf.

item.title: How To Navigate the Family Tree Tool Overview
item.description: Walk through video on the basics of Family Tree. Includes navigation, view types overview and descriptions of items on Family Tree.

item.title: How To Find Your Ancestors In Your Family Tree
item.description: Walk through video on how to use the descendancy view to find ancestors.

item.title: How To Add Photos to Your Family Tree
item.description: Walk through on how to use the Memories in Family Tree to Add photos and stories.

item.title: Share Reserved Ordinances with Family and Friends
item.description: Demonstration of steps to share a reserved name in FamilySearch.org with another family member.

item.title: Finding Our Cousins: Descendancy View
item.description: This video gives instructions on how to use the Descendancy view in Family Tree to find ancestors using the hinting feature.

item.title: New Indexing Website and Program
item.description: Get the inside scoop on the new and improved indexing tool and website now in development.

item.title: FamilySearch: When Your Family Tree Is Empty!
item.description: When your Family Tree is blank, this video provides basic instructions for quickly connecting you to the records of your ancestors that exist in FamilySearch

item.title: How to Print Your Pedigree Chart
item.description: A short demonstration of how to view and print your pedigree chart.

item.title: FamilySearch: Search Tips
item.description: Use these simple tips to get started with effective family history research on FamilySearch.

item.title: Introduction to the FamilySearch Family Tree
item.description: Here are seven steps to help you become more acquainted with the new Family Tree on familysearch.org.

item.title: Working Together in Family Tree - LDS
item.description: Here are several tips to help as you work with others in Family Tree. By following these tips you can further your family history research and help others with theirs.

item.title: Access to Records at FamilySearch.org
item.description: This video explain why FamilySearch gives access to free images of records and to paid sites. It explains how they get access to historical records from archives and how they work with companies to give everyone access to those records.

item.title: Episode 1: Quick Start
item.description: In this episode, you will learn the principles of finding a record for a known ancestor using records on familysearch.org. Watch host Jessie Davis help random individuals in a local café to find records of their ancestors in just 5 minutes.

item.title: Episode 2: The Research Process
item.description: In this episode, you will learn the method that FamilySearch suggests you use when starting your family history. Watch as host Jessie Davis teaches Tom about how she got started doing her genealogy.

item.title: Episode 3: Record What you Know
item.description: In this episode, you will learn the principles of starting your genealogy by writing down what you know about your family. Watch Jessie Davis describe pedigree charts and family group records, how to record names, dates, places, and jurisdiction.

item.title: Episode 4: Learn From Family
item.description: In this episode, you will learn the principles of starting your genealogy by talking to family. Watch host Jessie Davis as she challenges two of her friends to find out about their families by contacting family via phone and email.

item.title: Episode 5: Choose an Ancestor and Question
item.description: In this episode, you will learn the principles of how to choose the best ancestor so you can successfully find them in records and why that's important.

item.title: Episode 6: Locate Where Your Ancestors Lived
item.description: In this episode you’ll learn how to use maps, atlases, and gazetteers and why knowing your ancestor's location will help you find their records.

item.title: Episode 7: Records, an introduction
item.description: In this episode of 5 Minute Genealogy you will learn about different record types and the information you will find in each.

item.title: Episode 8: Find A Record
item.description: In this episode, you will learn the principles of finding a record for an ancestor using records using online resources and FamilySearch Centers.

item.title: Episode 9: Using Indexes To Find A Record
item.description: In this episode, you will learn what an index is and how to improve your chances of finding the genealogical records you hope to find. Watch as Amy visits the family history library and gets a behind the scenes tour.

item.title: Episode 10: Using Name Variations To Find A Record
item.description: In this episode, you will learn how names change over the years and how you can use resources on the internet to identify ancestors that may have a different surname than you expect.

item.title: Episode 11: Find Help From Others Online
item.description: Learn how to use collaborative web sites such as wikis, forums, and online trees.

item.title: Episode 12: Write It Down
item.description: In this episode, learn why it’s important to keep good notes, what kind of information you should keep track of, and the best places to keep your notes.

item.title: Episode 13: Organize Your Records
item.description: In this episode you will learn how to organize the research that you have already done and establish a system to keep your future research organized.

item.title: Episode 14: Understand how records are created
item.description: In this episode, you will learn how to evaluate the information you found in records about your ancestor.

item.title: Episode 15: Share With Others
item.description: Learn why sharing your family history research is important and the best ways to share your research.

item.title: Episode 16: Completing Your Research
item.description: In this episode you will learn what to do now that you have been around the wheel of success. You will also be introduced to the help resources available from FamilySearch. Your five minute challenge is to keep going.

item.title: Episode 17: Get Help In-Person
item.description: Today you'll learn about places where you can get one-on-one help with your genealogy.

item.title: Episode 18: Get Help from Others Researching the Same Name
item.description: Learn how online researches and genealogical societies can help you connect with people who may be researching your same ancestor.

item.title: Episode 19: I Want to Interview a Living Relative
item.description: In this episode, learn the do’s and don’ts of interviewing your living relatives. Learn what not to do from Tom’s mistakes, and learn the best ways to conduct and interview from Jessie with help from her friends.

item.title: Episode 20: I Want to Learn More About Sourcing
item.description: In this episode, learn more details about sourcing your records. Learn what details you should record to help others find your sources. You will learn the quickest way to make sure that your work is remembered.

item.title: Indexing Makes a Difference
item.description: Indexing is vital to family history research and helps people find and connect with their ancestors by making records searchable online.

item.title: Redeeming the Dead Redeemed Me
item.description: Stephen Jezek was able to feel the Spirit again, overcome addictions, and get baptized because of his experience indexing. Learn how family history can increase personal righteousness in your ward and stake.

item.title: Indexing is Vital
item.description: This short video demonstrates how indexing is vital to making records searchable online for temple and family history work.

item.title: I love indexing: Markus Bolte
item.description: Markus Bolte has six children and loves spending time with them whenever he can. Markus loves indexing.

item.title: One Million Names Indexed
item.description: The Sacramento, California (United States) Stake made a goal to index one million names in one month. They didn’t know what an impact it would have on the stake. View this video to see the blessings that come from indexing and family history.

item.title: I love indexing: Zhanna Bilchuck
item.description: Zhanna Bilchuck is an engineer from Kyiv. She likes to be busy and help other people. Zhanne loves indexing.

item.title: I love indexing: Mackenzie Hughes
item.description: Mackenzie Hughes is a young busy student in Chorley, England. Mackenzie loves indexing.

item.title: The Chorley Experience
item.description: The Chorley, England, stake received many blessings by participating in indexing. Watch this video to learn how indexing can increase temple and priesthood blessings in your area.

item.title: Obituary Indexing Announcement at RootsTech 2014
item.description: Dennis Brimhall and Captain Jack Starling announce a new initiative to index obituaries on familysearch.org

item.title: A Voice Said, "I am Not a Son"
item.description: Indexing is a monumental, spiritual work where help is given in both directions, within and beyond the veil.

item.title: FamilySearch Indexing: How It Works
item.description: This animated video gives a light-hearted, volunteer-level explanation of how indexing works and why it is important.

item.title: International Indexing Success
item.description: Learn from other stake indexing directors and priesthood leaders around the world how to gauge your success.

item.title: Priesthood Leader Panel
item.description: A panel of priesthood leaders and stake indexing directors will discuss how to effectively work together toward indexing success.

item.title: New Indexing Website and Program
item.description: Get the inside scoop on the new and improved indexing tool and website now in development.

item.title: A Message from the Managing Director
item.description: Hear from Elder Dennis C. Brimhall, managing director of the Family History Department and CEO of FamilySearch, provide motivation and direction for stake indexing directors.

item.title: I Love Indexing: Kaylie Sorensen
item.description: Kaylie Sorensen talks about her family, her interests, and shares her testimony of temple and family history work. She discusses how indexing has helped her feel the Spirit in her life.

item.title: I Love Indexing: Fernando Motta
item.description: Fernando Motta talks about his family and how they like to spend time together. He shares his testimony of temple and family history work and discusses how indexing has strengthened his family.

item.title: I Love Indexing: Davi de Silva
item.description: Davi da Silva talks about his interest in basketball and shares how he joined the Church. He discusses how family history and indexing has blessed his life.

item.title: Help Index the US Immigration & Naturalization Community Project
item.description: Volunteers are indexing immigration records as part of the US Immigration & Naturalization Community Project, making over 100 million records freely searchable online so everyone with US immigrant ancestors can discover their stories. Join today!

item.title: The US Immigration And Naturalization Project
item.description: Volunteers with the US Immigration & Naturalization Community Project make it possible for researchers worldwide to discover the stories of their US immigrant ancestors. We've already indexed millions of records, but there's more to do. Come join!

item.title: Sacramento Stake Indexing OMNI Project Trailer
item.description: The members of the Sacramento Stake participate in the OMNI project to index one million names for family history and temple work.

item.title: Indexing Training: The Difference
item.description: People from around the world can now make a difference and help others in their family history research. Indexing is a way to give back and further the work of genealogy.

item.title: Indexing Training: Recruiting
item.description: Anyone interested in family history can help. No special skills are required. Whether young or old, beginner or expert, discover your family tree by talking to people about indexing and looking for opportunities to teach.

item.title: Indexing Training: Overview
item.description: Indexing is a way that records can be converted into digital images, stored online, and provides us with an easy way to learn about our families and preserve their historical records from around the world.

item.title: Indexing Training: Leadership
item.description: Learn how to index through shadow leadership that will help encourage and motivate you to set goals that are meaningful to your family.

item.title: Indexing Training: FamilySearch Training
item.description: Overwhelmed with how to start indexing? Training lessons are available that will help you correctly and efficiently begin your FamilySearch index.

item.title: Elder and Sister Dickey – Washington DC North Mission
item.description: The Dickeys wake up each morning with the opportunity to change lives on both sides of the veil: preserving records to facilitate work for the dead and serving and sharing the gospel with the living.

item.title: "I'm a FamilySearch Missionary" Elder Marco Fernandes
item.description: Elder Marco Fernandes from Sao Paulo, Brazil explains what it is like to be a FamilySearch missionary.

item.title: Record Preservation Missionary in Peru
item.description: You can be like Brother and Sister Valientas, preservation missionaries in your own stake.

item.title: International Service Opportunities for Records Preservation Senior Missionaries
item.description: Would you like to serve a mission in a foreign country? Watch missionaries digitizing genealogical records at an Archive in Peru. Learn from their missionary experience.

item.title: I'm a FamilySearch Missionary - Sister Irene Tolley
item.description: Sister Irene Tolley from Cardston, Alberta, Canada explains what it is like to be a FamilySearch missionary.

item.title: I'm a FamilySearch Missionary - Elder David Redd
item.description: Elder David Redd from Cardston, Alberta, Canada explains what it is like to be a FamilySearch missionary serving from home.

item.title: FamilySearch Records Preservation Missionaries
item.description: Is this missionary experience for you? Watch missionaries digitizing genealogical records in archives domestically and internationally. Learn from their missionary experience.

item.title: I'm a FamilySearch Missionary-Elder and Sister Busker
item.description: Elder David Busker and Sister Leora Busker share how serving as FamilySearch missionaries has strengthened them as a couple and revitalized their lives.

item.title: A Day in the Life of a FamilySearch Missionary-Elder Allen Forsyth
item.description: What is it like to be a FamilySearch missionary? Elder Allen Forsyth explains what has helped him to be an effective missionary.

item.title: A Day in the Life of a FamilySearch Missionary in Training-Sister Queen
item.description: What is it like to be a FamilySearch missionary in training? Sister Lynnel Queen explains the training experience.

item.title: I'm A FamilySearch Missionary: Sister Horning
item.description: Sister Horning shares her experience as a FamilySearch service missionary.

item.title: Missionaries More Fully Converted
item.description: A mission president describes the dramatic change in his missionaries once they began using family history as a finding tool. Their efforts led to greater success in baptisms and to missionaries becoming more fully converted.

item.title: They Wanted to Go Back
item.description: As new converts attend the temple to do baptisms for their own family, they feel the Spirit, their testimonies are strengthened, and they become truly converted.

item.title: We Lost My Mother
item.description: A convert who lost his mother in a car accident explains how the message of eternal families led him to be baptized so that he could do the temple work for his mother.

item.title: Just One Word: Family
item.description: A husband and wife, who recently returned to Church activity, describe the peace and happiness they felt in doing baptisms for their ancestors and being sealed together as a family.

item.title: And There's Temples On It!
item.description: A husband and wife, who recently returned to Church activity, describe the joy of sharing the gospel on both sides of the veil, and the blessings of becoming an eternal family.

item.title: It Helped Me Go On a Mission
item.description: Young people describe how their involvement in family history and temple work strengthened their testimonies of the gospel and prepared them for full-time missionary service.

item.title: I Want to Enter the Temple
item.description: An investigator attends Sacrament meeting for the first time and is so touched by the Spirit that she wants to enter the temple as soon as possible.

item.title: And Now I'm Going to Be Baptized
item.description: A widow describes how learning the doctrine of family history and temple work provided the hope that prepared her for baptism and led to her sealing in the temple.

item.title: I Couldn’t Explain the Feeling
item.description: A convert to the Church tells how doing family history research helped her to feel the Spirit and prepared her heart to receive the gospel message.

item.title: Using Family History To Further Missionary Efforts
item.description: Missionaries describe how they can use family history in their missionary efforts.

item.title: Family History and Missionary Work-Teaching
item.description: Full-time missionaries teaching the plan of salvation through temple and family history work.

item.title: Family History and Missionary Work-Finding
item.description: Full-time missionaries using family history in their efforts to find people to teach.

item.title: Family History and Missionary Work-Retention
item.description: Full-time missionaries using temple and family history work in their convert retention efforts.

item.title: Family History and Missionary Work-Activation
item.description: Full-time missionaries using temple and family history work in their activation efforts.

item.title: Strengthen Families: Jess Family Condensed
item.description: The story of the Jess Family and how family history and temple work brought them closer together. - Condensed

item.title: Activation: Paul Felix
item.description: Paul Felix became an Elder before entering the Air Force. After getting married he always thought his wife would join the church. Now after years of inactivity and the passing of his wife he is coming back to church and going to the temple.

item.title: Missionary Work And Retention: Georgia Elias
item.description: Georgia Elias is converted to the gospel through family history work and begins her journey to the temple.

item.title: New Members And Retention: Dauphinee Family
item.description: After getting married and starting a family, Michael Dauphinee and his wife Jessica felt the need to go to church. See how family history has helped them grow in the gospel.
